chapter.title: Nexus Atlassian Crowd Plugin
chapter.para: Atlassian's Crowd is a single sign-on and identity management product that many organizations use to consolidare user accounts and control which users and groups have access to which applications. Nexus Professional contains an optional security plugin that allows you to configure Nexus to authenticate against an Atlassian Crowd instance. Form more information about Atlassian Crowd, go to http://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/.

section.title: Installing the Crowd Plugin
section.para: When you downloaded Nexus Professional, you also download a few optional plugins including the Nexus Crowd plugin. This plugin is located in the \${NEXUS_HOME}/runtime/apps/nexus/optional-plugins directory under security-crowd-realm-${nexus.version}. To install this plugin in Nexus:

listitem.para: Copy the security-crowd-realm-${nexus.version}/ directory from \${NEXUS_HOME}/runtime/apps/nexus/optional-plugins to \${NEXUS_HOME}/runtime/apps/nexus/plugin-repository.
Once the optional User Account plugin has been copied to the plugin-repository/ directory, restart Nexus and the User Account plugin will be installed.

section.title: Configuring the Crowd Plugin
section.para: Once the Atlassian Crowd plugin is installed, restart Nexus and login as a user with Administrative privileges. To configure the Crowd plugin, click on the Crown Configuration in the Securty section of the Nexus menu as shown in .

figure.title: Crowd Menu Link under the Security Section of the Nexus Menu

section.para: Clicking on the Crowd Configuration link will load the form shown in . This configuration panel contains all of the options that needs to be configured to connect your Nexus instance to Crowd for authorization and authentication.
The following sections outline all of the sections of the Crowd Configuration Pane.

section.title: Crowd Access Settings
section.para: The Access Settings section of the Crowd configuration is shown in . This section contains the following, required fields:

listitem.para: This field contains the application name of a Crowd application. This value should match the value in the Name field of the form shown in .
This field contains the application password of a Crowd application. This value should match the value in the Password field of the form shown in .
This is the URL of the Crowd Server, this URL should be accessible to the Nexus process as it is the URL that Nexus will use to connect to Crowd's SOAP services.

The number of minutes that a Crowd authentication is valid for. This value is in units of minutes, and a value of 30 means that Nexus will only require reauthentication is more than 30 minutes have elapsed since a previously authenticated user has accessed Nexus.
If clicked, Use Groups allows Nexus to use Crowd Groups when calculating Nexus Roles. When selected, you can map a Nexus Role to a Crowd Group.

section.title: Crowd HTTP Settings
section.para: You can control the concurrency of connections to Crowd in the HTTP Settings section shown in . If you have a high-traffic instance of Nexus, you will want to limit the number of simultaneous connections to the Crowd server to a reasonable value like 20. The HTTP Timeout specifies the number of milliseconds Nexus will wait for a response from Crowd. A value of zero for either of these properties indicates that there is no limit to either the number of connections or the timeout.

section.title: Crowd HTTP Proxy Settings
section.para: If your Nexus installation is connecting to Crowd via an HTTP Proxy server, the HTTP Proxy Settings section of the Crowd Configuration allows you to specify the host, port, and credentials for a HTTP Proxy server. The HTTP Proxy Settings section is shown in .

section.title: Miscellaneous Settings
section.para: The miscellaneous settings section shown in , allows you to configure settings that control the name of the Single Sign-on cookie and the various keys that are used to retrieve values that relate to authentication and the auth token. This dialog is only relevant if you have modified optional Crowd settings in your \${CROWD_HOME}/etc/crowd.properties. For more information about customizing these options see the Atlassian Crowd documentation.

section.title: Adding the Crowd Authentication Realm
section.para: Once you have configured Nexus to connect to Crowd, you must select the Crowd authorization realm from the list of available realms in your Nexus Server settings. , shows the Security settings section in the Nexus Server configuration. To load the Nexus server configuration panel, click on Server under Administration in the Nexus menu. Drag Crowd from the list of available realms to the list of selected realms and then save the Nexus server configuration.

section.title: Configuring a Nexus Application in Crowd
section.para: To connect Nexus to Atlassian's Crowd, you will need to configure Nexus as an application in Crowd. To do this, login to Crowd as a user with Administrative rights, and click on the Applications tab. Once you click on this tab, you should see two options under the Applications tab: Search Applications and Add Application. Click on Add Application to display the form shown in , and create a new application with the following values in the Details tab of the Add Application form:
Choose a password for this application that your Nexus instance will use to authenticate with the Crowd server, and then click on the Next button.

Clicking on Next will advance the form to the Connection tab shown in . In this tab you need to configure the URL of the application and the remote IP address. , shows the Connection form configured for a local instance of Nexus. If you would configuring Crowd and Nexus in a production environment, you would supply the URL that users would use to load Nexus in a web browser and you would supply an IP address which was not the loopback, 127.0.0.1 address. Once you have completed the Connection form, click on Next to advance to the Directories form.

figure.title: Creating a Nexus Crowd Application Connection

section.para: Clicking on Next advanced to the Directories form shown in . In this example, the Nexus application in Crowd is going to use the default "User Management" directory. Click on the Next button to advance to the "Authorisation" form.

figure.title: Creating a Nexus Crowd Application Directories

section.para: Clickin on the Next button advanced to the "Authorisation" form as shown in . If any of the directories selected in the previous form contain groups, each group is displayed on this form next to a checkbox. You can select "Allow all users" for a directory, or you can select specific groups which are allowed to authenticate to Crowd through the configured application. This option would be used if you wanted to limit access to Nexus to specific subgroups within a larger Crowd directory. If your entire organization is stored in a single Crowd directory, you may want to limit Nexus access to a Developers and Administrators group.

section.title: Mapping Crowd Groups to Nexus Roles
section.para: To map a Crowd Group to a Nexus Role, open up the Roles panel by clicking on the Roles link under the Security section of the Nexus menu. Click on the Add... button and select External Role Mapping as shown in .
Selecting External Role Mapping will show the Map External Role dialog shown in .

figure.title: Mapping an External Crowd Group to a Nexus Role

section.para: Once you have mapped a Crowd Group to a Nexus Role, these Roles will appear in the list of Nexus Roles with a mapping value of "Crowd" as shown in .
